Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
2/25/2022. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the prior CAP was not effective and what changes will
be made to ensure ongoing compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statues and rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The
facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
ADM 0330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Reports
Adoption workers must submit written quarterly progress reports
using the DHS-614, Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
One of six adoption assessments held a late quarterly update. The update was due
4/26/21 and was completed 5/4/21.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
Four of six foster care files held PATPs that were not signed within the required
timeframe.
File one: 8/2/21 signed by the foster parent on 10/15/21. 11/2/21 signed by the foster
parent on 12/13/21. 12/20/21 signed late by the foster parent on 2/7/22.
File two: 6/18/21 signed by the parent on 8/9/21 and foster parent on 10/21/21.
File three:10/19/21 signed late by the foster parent on 12/7/21.
File four: 1/4/22 did not have any signatures uploaded. 10/16/21 signed late by
parent on 12/9/21 and foster parent on 1/27/22. 7/8/21 signed late by parent on
9/10/21 and foster parent on 8/31/21. 4/20/21 signed late by parent on 5/28/21.
FOM 722-06H Case contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
4

Five of six foster care files held face-to-face contacts that were not entered into
MiSACWIS within the required timeframe.

FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary court
ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement. At
reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not required
after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
Two of six foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical passports
provided to the required case participants.
File one: The August 2021 passport did not have signatures, or any indication it was
provided to the parent or foster parent.
File two: the 4/19/21 and 7/16/21 passports did not have the foster parent signature,
or indicate it was provided to the foster parent.
FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of eighteen service plans was not approved by the supervisor within the
required timeframe. The 4/20/21 USP was approved on 5/5/21.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency was advised that review of updated service plans and medical
passports via video conference was an acceptable alternative when face-to-
face contact was not possible due to illness. The agency was advised to
document this review, then obtain signatures electronically, or in person when
able.
 The agency was advised to assure follow-up is completed with DCWL for all
adult household member clearances. The agency should contact their
consultant for assistance when a clearance has not been returned timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
5

The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP, approved 4/21/21, was the
result of the 3/5/21 interim review. During this review there were very few violations;
only one repeat violation was found. The agency was found to have successful
implementation of the 2021 CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment, dated 2/4/22, was reviewed and discussed
during the entrance meeting. The agency reported successful implementation of the
CAP without significant barriers. The agency has reviewed the CAP monthly among
the leadership team and reviewed data to assess compliance. Supervisors are also
utilizing “intentional” supervision to review compliance with staff.
The agency reported working with other branches of Bethany Christian Services
collaboratively to share best practice information and problem solve. The agency
continues to use the Monthly Management Report, Book of Business, and Info View.
The Program Manager provides a breakdown of the information to supervisors to
address any low compliance issues. Supervisors reported that timely entry of case
contacts is still challenging at times, due to staff turn-over, new staff, and a lack of
time for supervisors to diligently follow up and monitor compliance. However, they
continue to strategize to address this area. In addition, the agency has focused on
support and retention of foster parents over this past year, in an effort to maintain
placements.
Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two agency staff. Both staff reported having no
concerns about the agency. Both staff stated they have excellent supervisors that
provide help and support as needed. Neither staff had any suggestions regarding
improvements that could be made.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety alert:
During the 10/28/21 home visit to an unlicensed relative, the analyst found the home
did not have a working smoke detector, an alarm for the door exiting to the pool, and
there was a blanket over the crib railing. During the visit the caregiver removed the
blanket.
Resolution:
On 10/29/21 the foster care worker visited the home and reviewed safe sleep
requirements with the caregiver. The foster care worker also purchased and installed
door alarms for the pool. The alarms were tested by the worker and confirmed to
work. The foster care worker observed the caregiver’s installation of a smoke
detector and carbon monoxide detector. Both were tested and confirmed to work.
6

The worker provided photos of the safe sleep compliant crib, smoke and CO
detectors, and door alarms to DCWL on 10/29/21.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
